attributes.action: Ban petrol leaf blowers to improve public health and the environment
attributes.background: The Government should ban the sale and use of petrol leaf blowers, to stop all councils, public services and private individuals from using these, in order to reduce noise, carbon, air pollution and damage to soil.
attributes.additional_details:
Noise emissions, pollution and harm to soil life and inefficiency are the main reasons to stop using petrol leaf blowers and leaf blowers in general.
 
Petrol leaf blowers can be dangerously noisy, with those using them or nearby at risk of developing hearing problems. Leaf blowers can also be fatal to insect life which is vital for soil health, and release carcinogens and dust into the air.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Address the Energy, Climate and Environment crisis by investing in Renewables
attributes.background:
It's a no-brainer. This is a crisis the Government must address by the cheapest, quickest, most environmentally friendly, safest, and most job-creative means. 

Promote and increase Government investment in renewables.
attributes.additional_details:
Fossil fuels are ruining the climate and environment. Nuclear is unsafe.

Home-grown renewable energy and insulating our buildings so we don't lose the heat we produce will create more jobs, be cheaper and be quicker in reducing energy prices and global warming.
We ask the Government to think of the good of our country, our global environment and its people.
 
Increase Government investment in:
- Underwater turbines to harness tidal flows and estuary currents
- Wind farms
- Solar panels.
- Battery technology to store energy.
- Insulation of buildings.

Action, not words, are needed.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Ban the use of unpaid internships
attributes.background: Many internships require students to work obscene hours completely unpaid, creating an unfair class bias system, and exploiting students in a work environment. Companies should be required to pay their interns, more than just expenses being covered at a bare minimum.
attributes.additional_details: In the fashion industry, many internships are completely unpaid or with only a small amount of expenses covered. With students working normal hours (9-5) or even longer during certain periods it is unlikely students can manage a paid job alongside. Not only does this create an unfair class bias system within the industry and can force and encourage the exploitation of students within a working environment.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Create statutory procedures for sexual offence complaints in all universities
attributes.background: We are calling for a statutory procedures written by the government in partnership with survivors of, professional advocates against, and experts in sexual violence and abuse, that every university in the UK is mandated to follow when investigating complaints of sexual offences.
attributes.additional_details: Self-serving institutions are not listening. Their indifference to the safety of their students is evidenced by absent safeguarding policies, difficult reporting procedures, inadequate investigations, and toxic campus environments. Many of those who are responsible for supporting students have proven to be incompetent at best, and complicit at worst. The government must step in and demand change to address the inconsistencies in student safety and support across universities in the UK.

departments.name: Department for Education

attributes.action: Ban petrol leaf blowers which harm human health, animals and the environment
attributes.background: Follow other parts of the world in banning the use of petrol leaf blowers, which have become ubiquitous in schools, playgrounds and gardens. There is no place for this toxic practice when so many greener, cleaner, quieter alternatives exist.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Do not weaken river pollution rules
attributes.background:
The head of the Environment Agency has endorsed a proposal to weaken laws on cleanliness of polluted rivers, lakes and coastlines after Brexit.

Campaigners say Sir James Bevan is trying to “rig the system” to cover up decades of failure by the agency.
attributes.additional_details:
https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2020/aug/19/environment-agency-chief-backs-plan-to-water-down-river-cleanliness-rules-james-bevan

Our environment laws should be getting better, not worse. This government is weakening and threatening laws associated with animal welfare and the environment. It needs to stop.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Work with Ofgem to increase use of voltage optimisation across UK power networks
attributes.background: The UK electricity Distribution Network operators are deliberately keeping the voltage high. The existing OFGEM regulations have no incentive for them to change behaviour. The Government should consider changing the voltage limits and introducing incentives which drive optimisation.
attributes.additional_details: Electricity network operators deliberately keep customer volts high. The regulations only incentivise a reduction in the number/duration of interruptions to supply. Quality of delivered electricity is ignored. This causes wasted energy, high bills, and excessive CO2 emissions. Now smart meters send live voltage readings to data centres and this has confirmed that the problem is universal. One regional network company has accepted the challenge to optimise the voltage by developing an innovative real time automatic voltage control system to keep the voltage lower for the benefit of customers and the environment. The forthcoming regulatory review should include mechanisms which incentivise voltage optimisation across the whole nation.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Include gardening in the National Curriculum
attributes.background: As part of their science classes, children could have an applied session to plant and harvest vegetables. In the process, they could learn the benefits of growing one's greens, composting & recycling & the benefits for the environment.
attributes.additional_details: Education is the basis of a good, responsible citizen. In light of the current climate, it is important that future generations understand the basis of a sustainable economy, food sourcing and waste management.

departments.name: Department for Education

attributes.action: Include funding for more school gardens in the 2020-21 school building programme
attributes.background: Ideally all schools should have a garden for health, systems learning, emotional & intellectual development, environmental resilience & sustainable work opportunities. Adapt a corner of a playground/sports field/car park to enable development of school curricula & fresh food for local communities.
attributes.additional_details: We know from decades of research globally that outdoor learning & 'garden school' pedgagogies are extremely beneficial for healthy development of children & youth, as well as for lifelong learning & health. We know from climate research that we urgently need to increase urban green space & protect biological diversity in our environment-locally, nationally & globally. Additionally, we know sustainable agricultural practices & food chains increase the resilience of local economies. A win-win.

departments.name: Department for Education

attributes.action: Ban the sale of small fish tanks without filtration being sold as goldfish bowls
attributes.background: The use of goldfish bowls of insufficient size and without filtration system can cause distress, suffering and death due to lack of oxygen transfer to the water, the lack of filtration causing toxic levels of ammonia to build up, and their inadequate size for fish.
attributes.additional_details:
The use of such bowls can break four of the Five Freedoms of animal welfare: that an appropriate environment should be provided, that animals are kept free from pain and disease, that animals should have sufficient space to express normal behaviour and that conditions should avoid mental suffering.
While the debate about fish feeling pain continues, the UK should maintain its strong animal welfare laws by stopping fish suffering with toxic poisoning and suffocation by banning goldfish bowls that do not have adequate filtration or meet certain capacity requirements.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Keep COVID secure Health Clubs open
attributes.background: Keep COVID secure Health Clubs open where areas are put into tier 3, or if the whole country goes into circuit breaking lockdown.
attributes.additional_details:
To try and maintain good mental health and fitness of their members and to ensure the employees can keep their jobs. Closing these facilites could have negative effects upon everyone and may result in smaller chains having to close their doors permanently.

Health Clubs with high levels of COVID-19 controls in place, such as gyms, can be safer than unregulated environments and the benefits of staying open outweigh closing such businesses.

departments.name: Cabinet Office

attributes.action: Legislate to prohibit transactions in cryptocurrencies in the UK
attributes.background: Legislate to prohibit the payment by or acceptance of cryptocurrencies by UK resident businesses or individuals, and require UK regulators (the FCA and PRA) to prohibit transactions by UK financial institutions in cryptocurrencies such as Bitcoin.
attributes.additional_details: Cryptocurrencies have no intrinsic value and can be a destabilising influence on society, and often used for criminal activity. Banning crypto transactions in the UK would impede criminals that rely on these currencies, and could also affect faith in the currency and so lead to a fall in prices, reducing the wealth and power of those holding cryptos. Cryptos are in no way essential to legitimate citizens and businesses, and the ‘mining’ of cryptos is harmful to the environment.

departments.name: HM Treasury

attributes.action: Reintroduce shielding with financial support
attributes.background: The people most at risk of death are no longer being protected by shielding outside of care homes. Those people will make up the majority of deaths during the second wave of COVID. Vulnerable children and adults are being forced to expose their families to risky school environments and workplaces
attributes.additional_details: With fines for parents that cannot risk sending children to school and no furlong or financial support forcing vulnerable people to work, many feel they have no choice but to risk death to comply with government policy. It appears that the government is now happy to sacrifice the vulnerable and extremely vulnerable population in stark contrast to its actions during the first wave.

departments.name: Department of Health and Social Care

attributes.action: Abolish HS2 to fund a greener future for Britain
attributes.background: Abolish HS2 and use the money saved to fund green projects in the country to help us move towards a safer future. HS2 itself is terrible for the environment and the money should be used to help resolve the climate crisis instead.
attributes.additional_details: We are at the brink of an irreversible climate catastrophe, and building HS2 is detrimental to our environment. If the money spent on HS2 was instead spent on funding green projects and movements, we could help prevent this catastrophe from happening and be a trailblazer for environmental change.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Require toys sold in the UK to have an environmental rating
attributes.background: When I buy a toy I want to make an informed choice and buy the most eco-friendly toys. Sometimes toys have excessive plastic packaging and only last 5 minutes before they break and go into landfill as they can’t be recycled. An environmental rating could help people make more eco-friendly purchases.
attributes.additional_details:
The rating can cover things like manufacturing, how far it’s flown, what the toy is made of, how long it will last, packaging.
 
This would mean people could choose not to buy toys that are more damaging for the environment. People want to help the environment but often don’t have the information to make the right choices.
 
£3.3 billion was spent on 330 million toys in 2020 in the UK. An environmental rating system should mean more of this money is spent on eco-friendly toys.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Require home owners who fell conservation area trees to fund urban tree planting
attributes.background:
Trees trap carbon dioxide, a greenhouse gas, and improve the urban environment.

About 60,000 trees in our city conservation areas are felled every year. Many are not replaced.

We want parliament to pass legislation to ensure more trees are planted in our towns and cities.
attributes.additional_details:
Local government lacks the funding to plant enough trees and has no obligation to plant. 

This project would be cost-neutral for local authorities and we 
 believe would receive widespread local support.

It would assist the UK in meeting its carbon footprint target.
Most trees in conservation areas are not protected by Tree Protection Orders. Trees may be felled for good reasons, e.g. subsidence or for development. We seek legislation to ensure adequate replacement planting takes place in the urban locality.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban the import and sale of real fur in the UK
attributes.background: Polls suggest the majority of the public in the UK are against the import and sale of real fur due to the cruelty involved and the harm that the fur industry does to the environment. The Government should ban all imports and sales of real fur in the UK.
attributes.additional_details:
On fur factory farms thousands of wild animals are forced to spend their whole lives crammed into small wire-mesh cages. These conditions cause suffering and cruelty both physical and psychological.
Other animals killed for fur are trapped in the wild using leg hold traps. These devices crush the animals bones and they can spend hours or even days in agony, before the trapper returns.
Some of these animals are gassed, bludgeoned, or drowned and some are skinned alive.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban all fireworks permanently, including displays.
attributes.background: Ban all fireworks in the UK permanently, to include firework displays. Public and private displays to be fully banned.
attributes.additional_details: Fireworks are dangerous, disruptive to lives and unsettling for many people, animals and wildlife. They cause extreme fear. They are excessively loud and set off at unsociable hours disturbing sleep. Firework remains are not pleasant to clean up, dangerous for our animals and wildlife if consumed, get stuck or tangled up.  Fireworks can cause horrific injuries which can be life changing or worse if handled incorrectly. They can be fatal to animals and wildlife.  They are not good for our environment. Please ban fireworks permanently.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Make driving theory tests available to take online
attributes.background: Throughout the 3 lockdown periods, learner drivers have been faced with the disappointment of cancelled theory tests, practical tests and driving lessons. As education has gone online, it is time for theory tests to be added online to enable leaners to take tests in a covid safe environment.
attributes.additional_details:
With blockers that could be added to prevent use of the internet to find answers, the potential to video call and share screens, there is no reason why theory tests should not be accessible online.
With learner drivers being given a major disadvantage and disregarded, allowing some form of normality is the least the government could do.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Ban the release of any untreated raw sewage and separate rainwater from sewage
attributes.background:
1) Legislate for new build planning and retrospective action to keep rainwater separate from any raw sewage prior to the treatment of the raw sewage.
 
2) Require water companies to have sufficient water treatment facilities to meet raw sewage treatment requirements for their catchment area.
attributes.additional_details: Recent events have highlighted the dangers to our population through sewage-based water-borne viruses and the results of any pollution of our rivers, lakes and coasts caused by the release of any untreated raw sewage. The use of outdated systems and practices within the water industry has to cease. The water industry is responsible for ensuring that the environment is not a dumping ground for its contaminated waste and that the population is not placed at risk through its inability to change.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban clothing from being imported into the UK on plastic hangers
attributes.background: Millions of plastic hangers are shipped into the UK every year by our high street retailers. This plastic production has a huge impact on the environment in China and creates a huge amount of plastic waste after garments are purchased.
attributes.additional_details:
Almost all retailers ship garments on hangers into their stores. These garments range from Lingerie and swimwear to Coats. 

These products would easily be hung when they arrive in store (as some retailers already do) which would reduce our plastic waste dramatically. 

This would be a small step to make our retailers more environmentally friendly and reduce plastic waste.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Include Fairtrade bananas in the free fruit for schools scheme.
attributes.background: Every day, approx 2.3m children aged 4-7 in state-funded schools receive a free piece of fruit through the School Fruit and Vegetable Scheme (SFVS). The SFVS is funded by the Department of Health. The bananas included in this scheme are not Fairtrade - we want the Government to change this.
attributes.additional_details:
Bananas carrying the FAIRTRADE Mark have been produced by organisations or plantations that meet the Fairtrade standards. These standards include protection of workers’ rights and the environment and payment of the Fairtrade Minimum Price and an additional Fairtrade Premium to invest in business or community projects. 

Changing all the bananas in the SVFS would have an incredible impact on the life chances of the farmers that grow them and also increase awareness of Fairtrade in children.

departments.name: Department for Education

attributes.action: Review the route and construction plans for HS2 for environmental reasons
attributes.background: Current plans for HS2 involve the destruction of woodlands and use of unsustainable building materials.
attributes.additional_details:
We want all ancient woodland left untouched and modern, environmentally friendly materials to be used, not materials like concrete.
 
This petition is not saying stop HS2, but is calling on the Government to review the route and construction plans for this project, because of the concerns of people who care about our environment and wildlife and we want to reduce the irreversible destruction to our ancient woodlands.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Reduce the maximum working hours so people can do a four day week
attributes.background: This petition asks the Government to look at the evidence and consider piloting this approach.
attributes.additional_details:
Numerous research projects have indicated that employee well-being is improved, as is productivity and profitability. More free time means more spending in the leisure sector and less commuting which is better for our environment. We need to measure performance on output not time.
 
If Covid has taught us anything it’s that the old ways of working can change! Our family life, wellbeing and environment will all benefit.

departments.name: Home Office

attributes.action: Review the role of juries in rape trials.
attributes.background: We call on the government to consider whether jurors on rape trials should be vetted, trained or even replaced by a panel of experts trained in all aspects of sexual behaviour and violence.
attributes.additional_details: < 2% of reported rape cases go to trial. The police and CPS won’t put forward cases that won’t get past a jury. Based on YouGov research from 2018 on ‘Public Attitudes to Sexual Consent’, on average four members of a jury could think that rape by coercion isn’t rape, three could think that rape in a relationship isn’t rape and one could be unsure if rape when the other person is drunk or asleep is rape. We live in a society where misogyny is rife, where rape culture is creating a hostile environment for some schoolgirls, where some men send vile messages to women who speak out about harassment, and where even some police have been exposed as thinking it’s ok to joke about raping women. Victims deserve justice and the current system only rarely delivers it.

departments.name: Ministry of Justice

attributes.action: Ban UK imports of soy not certified as being grown sustainably
attributes.background: The growing of soy beans in environmentally sensitive regions (e.g. the Amazon Rainforest) is helping to fuel deforestation and climate change.
attributes.additional_details:
Much of these soy products are exported to the UK for animal feeds, and some for direct human consumption, where alternatives products are available
The UK government has a responsibility to reduce environmental impacts. This includes indirect impact via consumption.
 
Much soy in the UK is used for animal feed (~75% by weight), so its environmental damage is not seen by the consumer. The UK government needs to ban imports of soy where it cannot be certified that its production is not negatively impacting the environment, pushing our production markets to use more environmentally friendly sources of soy or alternatives products altogether.

departments.name: Department for International Trade

attributes.action: Increase TfL emergency funding to help protect bus routes in London
attributes.background: The Government has required Transport for London (TfL) to make savings as a condition of its emergency funding, and as a result TfL is proposing to reduce the number of kilometres travelled by its buses by 4% by 2024/25. The Govt should increase TfL’s funding so it doesn’t have to cut bus routes.
attributes.additional_details:
The proposed loss of many routes will surely impact many bus users, many of whom cannot use any other form of transport (for physical reasons). It will surely increase transit costs, making transport unaffordable for many.

The reduction of bus mileage will also result in increased car and taxi use, which will in turn release more pollutants into the environment.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Fund the use of environmentally friendly PPE in hospitals and care settings
attributes.background: We want the government to increase funding for biodegradable PPE, or PPE that can be reused. This could discourage the production of non-biodegradable PPE so there is less of an impact on the planet.
attributes.additional_details: There are reports that regular PPE is going to waste every day in the NHS. The waste is then incinerated or even ends up in the oceans or landfill. It is very important to make a change to prevent devastating impacts to our environment and damage to much of the natural world. We have to take responsibility of this problem and take action.

departments.name: Department of Health and Social Care

attributes.action: Require the use of body cameras and regular assessment for doorstaff/bouncers
attributes.background: Deaths, assaults and sexual harassment has been seen across the UK by bouncers who abuse their position of authority. Currently, licences can still be given to those who have committed violent and sexual offences. A culture of complacency has allowed this to go on for too long.
attributes.additional_details:
To reduce the number of deaths, assaults and sexual attacks door staff should be required to wear body cameras and be can be assessed regularly based on their interactions and given training when needed. 

In the event of a criminal offence, both door staff and customer can have adequate evidence to help with the case. The cameras will deter door staff from creating hostile environments, talking inappropriately to women and will increase the level of safety within the establishment.

departments.name: Home Office

attributes.action: Make the removal of coarse fish illegal from rivers and waterways
attributes.background: Update laws to preserve the current fish in UK rivers and waterways, by changing legislation so it would be an illegal act to remove fish from a river or waterway.
attributes.additional_details: Therefore preserving the current fish stock and allowing the rivers and local environments to recover from the amount of fish that have been removed in recent times.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban outdoor heating and cooling units
attributes.background: Make the use of outdoor heaters and cooling units illegal as they are an unnecessary use of energy and damage the environment. Due to the Covid-19 pandemic, this ban could come into force after this winter. Announcing a ban now should discourage people from buying new heaters now.
attributes.additional_details:
It should help reduce the amount of fossil fuels our country is using, make the UK more likely to meet the requirements of the Paris Agreement (2017), and make the UK a more environmentally-friendly country.
 
If it is too cold to sit outside, wear a coat or sit inside. France have plans to ban outdoor heaters and cooling units after this winter; we should do the same. Other colder countries, like Sweden, manage without outdoor heaters. They simply wear more layers.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Run a Public Awareness Campaign about the Climate and Ecological Emergency
attributes.background: We need the government to run a ‘Climate and Ecological Awareness’ public information campaign that will reach as wide an audience as possible.  The government has carried out such campaigns in the past for issues that posed far less danger to our well-being, for example the anti-smoking campaign.
attributes.additional_details:
The UK Committee on Climate Change is telling us that we are not currently on track for our 2050 net-zero target and we are likely to see global warming of 2-4 degrees by the end of this century. This is far higher than the levels deemed ‘safe’ in the IPCC special report of 2018.   Many of us are oblivious to the damage that we wreak daily on our environment by our activities.

We all need to get involved in facing the challenge, so that the UK can be a role-model for the rest of the world.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Turn Marine Conservation Areas into No Take Zones
attributes.background: I ask the Government to improve the protection of UK marine life by implementing No Take Zones (NTZ). This can be achieved using existing Marine Conservation Area boundaries, authorities, technologies and criminal justice procedures. NTZs should support our fragile ecosystem and UK fish industry
attributes.additional_details:
NTZs, which include all fishing, mining and seabed disruption, would provide sanctuary for marine life. NTZs should nin turn supply the fishing permitted areas with a steady source of catch.
The Marine Management Organisation should be tasked with enforcement. They already require boats to have Vessel Monitoring Systems (GPS tracking). Breaching NTZs should be considered as assumed activity and thus as a Corporate Environment Crime. Such clear legislation will make management and prosecution easier.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Provide free bus passes for all over 60's
attributes.background: Currently, people living in London, Wales and Scotland can obtain a free bus pass at 60 years old, however in the rest of England, you can only obtain one when you are of pension age.
attributes.additional_details:
We believe this isn't fair or equitable, so call on the Government to provide free bus passes to all those who are over 60 years old. 

Providing these passes from 60 years old could also be better for the environment as it would encourage more people to use public transport, which could reduce car use.
 
I also wanted to let you know that this would only apply to England as this issue is somewhat devolved and the local authorities in Scotland and Wales would be free to change the age at which you can apply for a bus pass.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Stop schools selling or giving students single-use plastic water bottles
attributes.background:
We are pleading for the Government to stop schools across England from selling single-use plastic water bottles, or giving these to students.

We're saying no to single-use plastic water bottles in school. Please help support us in our mission.
attributes.additional_details:
We know that producing plastic bottles is bad for the planet. As a family, we spend a lot of time going around litter picking, we are keen to protect nature, we want to help protect and keep plastic-free for us and future generations. That’s why we want the Government to think of the environment and stop schools selling single-use plastic water bottles, or giving these to students.

 

Please help us to raise awareness of this issue by signing our petition, and hopefully, the Government will hear our collective voices and consider making a change.

departments.name: Department for Education

attributes.action: Ban plastic charity bags being delivered to every household
attributes.background: Ban charities from using plastic bags to collect unwanted clothing and unwanted household items. The majority of households don’t use these bags for this purpose and it is just contributing to the mountain of plastic bag waste.
attributes.additional_details: These plastic charity bags are delivered without our permission and it is a national disgrace that we allow this to happen. Free plastic supermarket bags were banned in order to help save the environment and wildlife and so should plastic charity bags.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban the sale and release of sky Lanterns & Balloons
attributes.background: Totally ban the sales and release of these products. Some local councils are taking action to tackle this but many people still let them off from their back gardens. Releasing these items causes harm to the environment, domestic animals, wildlife and farm stock.
attributes.additional_details: Common sense does not seem to work so the best thing to do is place an outright ban on these products.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Display environmental impact on all packaging and bags containing plastic
attributes.background: The global plastic problem is only increasing and recycling is not going to solve it on its own.
attributes.additional_details:
All packaging containing plastics including bags should display the message “This product contributes to the destruction of our oceans and this impacts human health”, so people see the environmental impact this packaging creates. 

We need to transition to biodegradable plastics such as hemp. Those who live oblivious to the situation deserve education as well as future generations being given a cleaner planet to live on. I want the government to do this to encourage people to demand sustainable solutions to the plastic problem to be able to hand future generations a better planet, that not only benefits humans but the environment and all other species.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban the sale and use of fake grass
attributes.background:
We want the Government to ban the sale and use of fake grass, so that it is illegal to sell or have fake grass on any property.
 
Artificial grass is bad for the environment, including local biodiversity.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban the sale of wet wipes in the UK unless bio-degradable
attributes.background: Ban wet wipes from sale in the UK (and similar products) unless they are eco-friendly and degradable to Water UK certification.
attributes.additional_details: The cost of removing "fat bergs", which include wet wipes, from sewers is now costing millions as they form so readily in our sewers. Banning these items when there are so many alternatives is long overdue. This is a measure that will also help the environment.  It might also have an educational effect of discouraging people from buying products that they then dispose of in an inappropriate way.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Automatically alert educational institutions if pupil test positive for Covid-19
attributes.background: I would like the Track and Trace process to be adapted to ensure a school, college or other educational institute are alerted directly in the event of a pupil testing positive.
attributes.additional_details:
It is possible for an infected student to go off sick, test positive and for the school not to know unless the parent alerts the school (which might not happen). This feels like a huge gap in the process that could easily be adapted by the track and trace team simply asking the pupil for their school name and then adding that as an additional contact.

This should help schools in understanding what is happening on site and will help provide a safer environment for both pupils and staff.

departments.name: Department of Health and Social Care

attributes.action: Protect Bumblebees and support increased bumblebee numbers
attributes.background: Help to save the diminishing habitats of bees from development and climate change by making bumblebees a protected species under UK law, banning harmful pesticides that kill bees, and providing funding to boost bee numbers across the country.
attributes.additional_details:
As one of the greatest pollinators, bees are essential in keeping the environment healthy and play a vital role in securing stable food supply. 

Without bees, millions of plants could die and the UK could fall further from meeting its environmental targets.

Action must be taken now to save this magnificent species from potential extinction on UK soil.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Make school uniform optional for students in secondary schools.
attributes.background: We would like the Government to make school uniforms optional for students in secondary schools, therefore allowing students to wear whatever clothes they find comfortable. This would allow students which struggle with uniform for reasons such as emotion, gender, and sensory issues to attend school.
attributes.additional_details: COVID-19 and the national lockdown has seen students home schooling themselves. Although this has been difficult, we've seen that students which struggle with their emotional health and wellbeing in school have been able to work from in their own comfortable environment wearing their own clothing. Polls of students that have been done in schools and on social media have shown that students would be more comfortable and productive in school wearing their own clothes.

departments.name: Department for Education

attributes.action: Require all workplaces to have at least one Mental Health First Aider
attributes.background: The Government should make it a requirement for at least 1 employee in every workplace to be trained in mental health and well-being, so they can provide support for other staff.
attributes.additional_details: Providing Mental health first aid is equally as important as the health and safety (First-Aid) regulations of 1981. Acting on mental health and well-being is essential as we ease out of lockdown and begin to head back into what will we be a completely new working environment. This will help employers and employees work productively whilst understanding the importance of mental health.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Establish a national tree-planting scheme for graduating students
attributes.background: It is vitally important to protect our environment, and tree planting is one way of helping to do so. Planting your own tree is very rewarding and has the potential to inspire and encourage local communities to protect and look after their own patches of nature.
attributes.additional_details: In the Philippines, it is a legal requirement for all graduating students from elementary school to college, to plant 10 trees each. The bill, "Graduation Legacy For the Environment Act," is estimated to plant 525 billion trees over the course of one generation. Our environment is at a tipping point, and we urgently need innovative solutions like this to not only combat the crisis, but also to encourage local communities to care and protect for their own patches of local nature.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban formaldehyde in motorhome/caravan toilet fluid products
attributes.background: Some blue toilet chemicals contain formaldehyde, a known human carcinogen. The government should ban the use of formaldehyde in motorhome/caravan toilet fluids because safer alternatives (including 100% natural products) are now commercially available.
attributes.additional_details:
Formaldehyde is a highly toxic systemic poison that is absorbed well by inhalation. The vapour is a severe respiratory tract and skin irritant and may cause dizziness or suffocation. Contact with formaldehyde solution may cause severe burns to the eyes and skin.

Fomaldehyde-based toilet fluids are unsuitable for all campsites with septic tanks and can seriously damage the natural environment if spilled.

We should not be allowing the use of such a dangerous ingredient in blue toilet fluids.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Require and fund training on autism for all staff in mainstream schools
attributes.background: In my experience, children with Autism are still widely misunderstood within mainstream schooling. This can have an enormous impact on not only their ability to learn but their mental health. We want the Government to require and fund training on autism for all staff in mainstream schools receive.
attributes.additional_details:
I visit schools, explaining about Autism and providing free resources and support within the mainstream environment. Schools are crying out for more help, and we want the Government to mandate and fund training for all staff in mainstream schools, to improve the experience of autistic students.

I know your original petition referred to your son, but we don’t publish petitions that contain personal information about minors, as they could be identifiable from the text of a petition, and name of the petition creator – which is published alongside a petition.

departments.name: Department for Education

attributes.action: Fund an NHS app for period tracking and sexual health advice for women.
attributes.background: Young women are now growing up in a digital environment, where sex ed is often monetised, unclear and dangerous. For the ordinary woman, the school sex ed curriculum may not answer all her questions, and the disadvantaged woman may not have access to sex education at all.
attributes.additional_details: Funding should be put aside for this app because it will help women and girls deal with these issues correctly, as many current apps are monetised meaning some women can’t access the expert advice on it; it should encourage safer sex; it could give more disadvantaged women access to this important information; it should make it clear that periods are medical and should be covered by our NHS and it could give a morale boost to the women in the workforce, aiding opportunity and prosperity.

departments.name: Department of Health and Social Care

attributes.action: Treat Carbon emissions as Hazardous Waste in planning process
attributes.background:
The Hazardous Waste Policy states:  “You must make sure hazardous waste produced or handled by your business in England causes no harm or damage. You have responsibilities known as your ‘duty of care’”

Emissions are currently not part of planning permissions.
attributes.additional_details:
Global Climate Change is proof that carbon-type emissions “are harmful to humans or the environment”.

When proposing new business premises, plans for safe disposal of Hazardous Waste are essential for approval. This should now be a requirement for all emissions (including Nitrous Oxide, Methane) that any new infrastructure will produce. This will help stop further increases in the national emissions at a point where we have recognised the urgent need to drastically lower them. It also encourages embedded corporate responsibility.

attributes.action: Right to paid leave for pregnant women in public-facing jobs for third trimester
attributes.background: I would like the Government to make it mandatory for employers to give pregnant women who are in their third trimester and work in public-facing roles 3 months leave on full pay, and not leave it to the discretion of their employers. This would help ensure pregnant women are not at risk at work.
attributes.additional_details:
There are many pregnant women out there who feel incredibly vulnerable working in roles where they are exposed to hundreds of contacts a day in environments where social distancing is not possible. Vulnerable workers deserve our protection.
 
The risks to pregnant women in their third trimester, and their babies, if they contract Covid-19 are well documented. Currently it is a lottery as to whether your employer offers you paid leave. Please end this ambiguity; protect mothers-to-be.
